         <header class="book-titlepage">
            <h1>Pericles, Prince of Tyre</h1>
         </header>
         <div class="lists-of-titles">

               </p>

                     </span>

                           </span>

                              <a href="#R.1.4.4">3. SCENE II.  The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.4.5">4. SCENE III.  The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>

                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>

                              <a href="#R.1.6.3">2. SCENE I.  Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>

                           <span>

                           </span>
                        </li>

                           </span>

                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.6.7">6. SCENE V.  Mytilene. A street before the brothel.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.6.8">7. SCENE VI.  The same. A room in the brothel.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                     </ul>
                  </li>
                  <li>

                     </span>
                     <ul class="toc">
                        <li>

                              <a href="#R.1.7.2">1. [Prologue]</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.7.3">2. SCENE I.  On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.7.4">3. SCENE II</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                           <span>
                              <a href="#R.1.7.5">4. SCENE III.  The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.</a>
                           </span>
                        </li>
                     </ul>
                  </li>
               </ul>

         <article class="preface" id="R.1.2">
            <header class="preface-titlepage">
               <h2>Dramatis Personae</h2>
            </header>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">ANTIOCHUS, king of Antioch.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">PERICLES, prince of Tyre.</span>
            </p>
            <table border="0" class="simplelist" summary="Simple list">
               <tr>
                  <td>
                     <span class="member">
                        <span class="personname">HELICANUS</span>
                        <span class="personname">ESCANES</span>
                     </span>
                  </td>
                  <td>
                     <span class="member">two lords of Tyre.</span>
                  </td>
               </tr>
            </table>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">SIMONIDES, king of Pentapolis.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">CLEON, governor of Tarsus.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">LYSIMACHUS, governor of Mytilene.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">CERIMON, a lord of Ephesus.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">THALIARD, a lord of Antioch.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">PHILEMON, servant to Cerimon.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">LEONINE, servant to Dionyza.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">Marshal. </span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">A Pandar. </span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">BOULT, his servant.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">The Daughter of Antiochus. </span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">DIONYZA, wife to Cleon.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">THAISA, daughter to Simonides.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">MARINA, daughter to Pericles and Thaisa.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">LYCHORIDA, nurse to Marina.</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">A Bawd. </span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, Sailors, Pirates, Fishermen, and Messengers. </span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">DIANA</span>
            </p>
            <p>
               <span class="personname">GOWER, as Chorus.</span>
            </p>
            <p>SCENE  Dispersedly in various countries.</p>
         </article>
         <article class="chapter" id="R.1.3">
            <header class="chapter-titlepage">
               <h2>Chapter 1. ACT I</h2>
            </header>
            <div class="lists-of-titles">
               <div class="toc">
                  <p>
                     <b>Table of Contents</b>
                  </p>
                  <ul class="toc">
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.3.2">1. [Prologue]</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.3.3">2. SCENE I.  Antioch. A room in the palace.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.3.4">3. SCENE II.  Tyre. A room in the palace.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.3.5">4. SCENE III.  Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.3.6">5. SCENE IV.  Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                  </ul>
               </div>
            </div>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.3.2">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>1. [Prologue]</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter GOWER</p>
               <p>Before the palace of Antioch</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">[GOWER]</div>
                     <div class="line">To sing a song that old was sung,</div>
                     <div class="line">From ashes ancient Gower is come;</div>
                     <div class="line">Assuming man's infirmities,</div>
                     <div class="line">To glad your ear, and please your eyes.</div>
                     <div class="line">It hath been sung at festivals,</div>
                     <div class="line">On ember-eves and holy-ales;</div>
                     <div class="line">And lords and ladies in their lives</div>
                     <div class="line">Have read it for restoratives:</div>
                     <div class="line">The purchase is to make men glorious;</div>
                     <div class="line">Et bonum quo antiquius, eo melius.</div>
                     <div class="line">If you, born in these latter times,</div>
                     <div class="line">When wit's more ripe, accept my rhymes.</div>
                     <div class="line">And that to hear an old man sing</div>
                     <div class="line">May to your wishes pleasure bring</div>
                     <div class="line">I life would wish, and that I might</div>
                     <div class="line">Waste it for you, like taper-light.</div>
                     <div class="line">This Antioch, then, Antiochus the Great</div>
                     <div class="line">Built up, this city, for his chiefest seat:</div>
                     <div class="line">The fairest in all Syria,</div>
                     <div class="line">I tell you what mine authors say:</div>
                     <div class="line">This king unto him took a fere,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who died and left a female heir,</div>
                     <div class="line">So buxom, blithe, and full of face,</div>
                     <div class="line">As heaven had lent her all his grace;</div>
                     <div class="line">With whom the father liking took,</div>
                     <div class="line">And her to incest did provoke:</div>
                     <div class="line">Bad child; worse father! to entice his own</div>
                     <div class="line">To evil should be done by none:</div>
                     <div class="line">But custom what they did begin</div>
                     <div class="line">Was with long use account no sin.</div>
                     <div class="line">The beauty of this sinful dame</div>
                     <div class="line">Made many princes thither frame,</div>
                     <div class="line">To seek her as a bed-fellow,</div>
                     <div class="line">In marriage-pleasures play-fellow:</div>
                     <div class="line">Which to prevent he made a law,</div>
                     <div class="line">To keep her still, and men in awe,</div>
                     <div class="line">That whoso ask'd her for his wife,</div>
                     <div class="line">His riddle told not, lost his life:</div>
                     <div class="line">So for her many a wight did die,</div>
                     <div class="line">As yon grim looks do testify.</div>
                     <div class="line">What now ensues, to the judgment of your eye</div>
                     <div class="line">I give, my cause who best can justify.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
            </section>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.3.3">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>2. SCENE I.  Antioch. A room in the palace.</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter ANTIOCHUS, Prince PERICLES, and followers</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Young prince of Tyre, you have at large received</div>
                     <div class="line">The danger of the task you undertake.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">I have, Antiochus, and, with a soul</div>
                     <div class="line">Embolden'd with the glory of her praise,</div>
                     <div class="line">Think death no hazard in this enterprise.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Bring in our daughter, clothed like a bride,</div>
                     <div class="line">For the embracements even of Jove himself;</div>
                     <div class="line">At whose conception, till Lucina reign'd,</div>
                     <div class="line">Nature this dowry gave, to glad her presence,</div>
                     <div class="line">The senate-house of planets all did sit,</div>
                     <div class="line">To knit in her their best perfections.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">See where she comes, apparell'd like the spring,</div>
                     <div class="line">Graces her subjects, and her thoughts the king</div>
                     <div class="line">Of every virtue gives renown to men!</div>
                     <div class="line">Her face the book of praises, where is read</div>
                     <div class="line">Nothing but curious pleasures, as from thence</div>
                     <div class="line">Sorrow were ever razed and testy wrath</div>
                     <div class="line">Could never be her mild companion.</div>
                     <div class="line">You gods that made me man, and sway in love,</div>
                     <div class="line">That have inflamed desire in my breast</div>
                     <div class="line">To taste the fruit of yon celestial tree,</div>
                     <div class="line">Or die in the adventure, be my helps,</div>
                     <div class="line">As I am son and servant to your will,</div>
                     <div class="line">To compass such a boundless happiness!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Prince Pericles,--</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">That would be son to great Antiochus.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Before thee stands this fair Hesperides,</div>
                     <div class="line">With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touch'd;</div>
                     <div class="line">For death-like dragons here affright thee hard:</div>
                     <div class="line">Her face, like heaven, enticeth thee to view</div>
                     <div class="line">Her countless glory, which desert must gain;</div>
                     <div class="line">And which, without desert, because thine eye</div>
                     <div class="line">Presumes to reach, all thy whole heap must die.</div>
                     <div class="line">Yon sometimes famous princes, like thyself,</div>
                     <div class="line">Drawn by report, adventurous by desire,</div>
                     <div class="line">Tell thee, with speechless tongues and semblance pale,</div>
                     <div class="line">That without covering, save yon field of stars,</div>
                     <div class="line">Here they stand martyrs, slain in Cupid's wars;</div>
                     <div class="line">And with dead cheeks advise thee to desist</div>
                     <div class="line">For going on death's net, whom none resist.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Antiochus, I thank thee, who hath taught</div>
                     <div class="line">My frail mortality to know itself,</div>
                     <div class="line">And by those fearful objects to prepare</div>
                     <div class="line">This body, like to them, to what I must;</div>
                     <div class="line">For death remember'd should be like a mirror,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who tells us life's but breath, to trust it error.</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll make my will then, and, as sick men do</div>
                     <div class="line">Who know the world, see heaven, but, feeling woe,</div>
                     <div class="line">Gripe not at earthly joys as erst they did;</div>
                     <div class="line">So I bequeath a happy peace to you</div>
                     <div class="line">And all good men, as every prince should do;</div>
                     <div class="line">My riches to the earth from whence they came;</div>
                     <div class="line">But my unspotted fire of love to you.</div>
                     <p>To the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS</p>
                     <div class="line">Thus ready for the way of life or death,</div>
                     <div class="line">I wait the sharpest blow, Antiochus.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Scorning advice, read the conclusion then:</div>
                     <div class="line">Which read and not expounded, 'tis decreed,</div>
                     <div class="line">As these before thee thou thyself shalt bleed.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Daughter</div>
                     <div class="line">Of all say'd yet, mayst thou prove prosperous!</div>
                     <div class="line">Of all say'd yet, I wish thee happiness!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Like a bold champion, I assume the lists,</div>
                     <div class="line">Nor ask advice of any other thought</div>
                     <div class="line">But faithfulness and courage.</div>
                     <p>He reads the riddle</p>
                     <div class="line">I am no viper, yet I feed</div>
                     <div class="line">On mother's flesh which did me breed.</div>
                     <div class="line">I sought a husband, in which labour</div>
                     <div class="line">I found that kindness in a father:</div>
                     <div class="line">He's father, son, and husband mild;</div>
                     <div class="line">I mother, wife, and yet his child.</div>
                     <div class="line">How they may be, and yet in two,</div>
                     <div class="line">As you will live, resolve it you.</div>
                     <div class="line">Sharp physic is the last: but, O you powers</div>
                     <div class="line">That give heaven countless eyes to view men's acts,</div>
                     <div class="line">Why cloud they not their sights perpetually,</div>
                     <div class="line">If this be true, which makes me pale to read it?</div>
                     <div class="line">Fair glass of light, I loved you, and could still,</div>
                     <p>Takes hold of the hand of the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS</p>
                     <div class="line">Were not this glorious casket stored with ill:</div>
                     <div class="line">But I must tell you, now my thoughts revolt</div>
                     <div class="line">For he's no man on whom perfections wait</div>
                     <div class="line">That, knowing sin within, will touch the gate.</div>
                     <div class="line">You are a fair viol, and your sense the strings;</div>
                     <div class="line">Who, finger'd to make man his lawful music,</div>
                     <div class="line">Would draw heaven down, and all the gods, to hearken:</div>
                     <div class="line">But being play'd upon before your time,</div>
                     <div class="line">Hell only danceth at so harsh a chime.</div>
                     <div class="line">Good sooth, I care not for you.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Prince Pericles, touch not, upon thy life.</div>
                     <div class="line">For that's an article within our law,</div>
                     <div class="line">As dangerous as the rest. Your time's expired:</div>
                     <div class="line">Either expound now, or receive your sentence.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Great king,</div>
                     <div class="line">Few love to hear the sins they love to act;</div>
                     <div class="line">'Twould braid yourself too near for me to tell it.</div>
                     <div class="line">Who has a book of all that monarchs do,</div>
                     <div class="line">He's more secure to keep it shut than shown:</div>
                     <div class="line">For vice repeated is like the wandering wind.</div>
                     <div class="line">Blows dust in other's eyes, to spread itself;</div>
                     <div class="line">And yet the end of all is bought thus dear,</div>
                     <div class="line">The breath is gone, and the sore eyes see clear:</div>
                     <div class="line">To stop the air would hurt them. The blind mole casts</div>
                     <div class="line">Copp'd hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is throng'd</div>
                     <div class="line">By man's oppression; and the poor worm doth die for't.</div>
                     <div class="line">Kings are earth's gods; in vice their law's</div>
                     <div class="line">their will;</div>
                     <div class="line">And if Jove stray, who dares say Jove doth ill?</div>
                     <div class="line">It is enough you know; and it is fit,</div>
                     <div class="line">What being more known grows worse, to smother it.</div>
                     <div class="line">All love the womb that their first being bred,</div>
                     <div class="line">Then give my tongue like leave to love my head.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>  Heaven, that I had thy head! he has found</div>
                     <div class="line">the meaning:</div>
                     <div class="line">But I will gloze with him.--Young prince of Tyre,</div>
                     <div class="line">Though by the tenor of our strict edict,</div>
                     <div class="line">Your exposition misinterpreting,</div>
                     <div class="line">We might proceed to cancel of your days;</div>
                     <div class="line">Yet hope, succeeding from so fair a tree</div>
                     <div class="line">As your fair self, doth tune us otherwise:</div>
                     <div class="line">Forty days longer we do respite you;</div>
                     <div class="line">If by which time our secret be undone,</div>
                     <div class="line">This mercy shows we'll joy in such a son:</div>
                     <div class="line">And until then your entertain shall be</div>
                     <div class="line">As doth befit our honour and your worth.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exeunt all but PERICLES</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">How courtesy would seem to cover sin,</div>
                     <div class="line">When what is done is like an hypocrite,</div>
                     <div class="line">The which is good in nothing but in sight!</div>
                     <div class="line">If it be true that I interpret false,</div>
                     <div class="line">Then were it certain you were not so bad</div>
                     <div class="line">As with foul incest to abuse your soul;</div>
                     <div class="line">Where now you're both a father and a son,</div>
                     <div class="line">By your untimely claspings with your child,</div>
                     <div class="line">Which pleasure fits an husband, not a father;</div>
                     <div class="line">And she an eater of her mother's flesh,</div>
                     <div class="line">By the defiling of her parent's bed;</div>
                     <div class="line">And both like serpents are, who though they feed</div>
                     <div class="line">On sweetest flowers, yet they poison breed.</div>
                     <div class="line">Antioch, farewell! for wisdom sees, those men</div>
                     <div class="line">Blush not in actions blacker than the night,</div>
                     <div class="line">Will shun no course to keep them from the light.</div>
                     <div class="line">One sin, I know, another doth provoke;</div>
                     <div class="line">Murder's as near to lust as flame to smoke:</div>
                     <div class="line">Poison and treason are the hands of sin,</div>
                     <div class="line">Ay, and the targets, to put off the shame:</div>
                     <div class="line">Then, lest my lie be cropp'd to keep you clear,</div>
                     <div class="line">By flight I'll shun the danger which I fear.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
               <p>Re-enter ANTIOCHUS</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">He hath found the meaning, for which we mean</div>
                     <div class="line">To have his head.</div>
                     <div class="line">He must not live to trumpet forth my infamy,</div>
                     <div class="line">Nor tell the world Antiochus doth sin</div>
                     <div class="line">In such a loathed manner;</div>
                     <div class="line">And therefore instantly this prince must die:</div>
                     <div class="line">For by his fall my honour must keep high.</div>
                     <div class="line">Who attends us there?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter THALIARD</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">Doth your highness call?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Thaliard,</div>
                     <div class="line">You are of our chamber, and our mind partakes</div>
                     <div class="line">Her private actions to your secrecy;</div>
                     <div class="line">And for your faithfulness we will advance you.</div>
                     <div class="line">Thaliard, behold, here's poison, and here's gold;</div>
                     <div class="line">We hate the prince of Tyre, and thou must kill him:</div>
                     <div class="line">It fits thee not to ask the reason why,</div>
                     <div class="line">Because we bid it. Say, is it done?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">My lord,</div>
                     <div class="line">'Tis done.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Enough.</div>
                     <p>Enter a Messenger</p>
                     <div class="line">Let your breath cool yourself, telling your haste.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Messenger</div>
                     <div class="line">My lord, prince Pericles is fled.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">As thou</div>
                     <div class="line">Wilt live, fly after: and like an arrow shot</div>
                     <div class="line">From a well-experienced archer hits the mark</div>
                     <div class="line">His eye doth level at, so thou ne'er return</div>
                     <div class="line">Unless thou say 'Prince Pericles is dead.'</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">My lord,</div>
                     <div class="line">If I can get him within my pistol's length,</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll make him sure enough: so, farewell to your highness.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">ANTIOCHUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Thaliard, adieu!</div>
                     <p>Exit THALIARD</p>
                     <div class="line">Till Pericles be dead,</div>
                     <div class="line">My heart can lend no succor to my head.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
            </section>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.3.4">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>3. SCENE II.  Tyre. A room in the palace.</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter PERICLES</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>To Lords without</span>  Let none disturb us.--Why should</div>
                     <div class="line">this change of thoughts,</div>
                     <div class="line">The sad companion, dull-eyed melancholy,</div>
                     <div class="line">Be my so used a guest as not an hour,</div>
                     <div class="line">In the day's glorious walk, or peaceful night,</div>
                     <div class="line">The tomb where grief should sleep, can breed me quiet?</div>
                     <div class="line">Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them,</div>
                     <div class="line">And danger, which I fear'd, is at Antioch,</div>
                     <div class="line">Whose aim seems far too short to hit me here:</div>
                     <div class="line">Yet neither pleasure's art can joy my spirits,</div>
                     <div class="line">Nor yet the other's distance comfort me.</div>
                     <div class="line">Then it is thus: the passions of the mind,</div>
                     <div class="line">That have their first conception by mis-dread,</div>
                     <div class="line">Have after-nourishment and life by care;</div>
                     <div class="line">And what was first but fear what might be done,</div>
                     <div class="line">Grows elder now and cares it be not done.</div>
                     <div class="line">And so with me: the great Antiochus,</div>
                     <div class="line">'Gainst whom I am too little to contend,</div>
                     <div class="line">Since he's so great can make his will his act,</div>
                     <div class="line">Will think me speaking, though I swear to silence;</div>
                     <div class="line">Nor boots it me to say I honour him.</div>
                     <div class="line">If he suspect I may dishonour him:</div>
                     <div class="line">And what may make him blush in being known,</div>
                     <div class="line">He'll stop the course by which it might be known;</div>
                     <div class="line">With hostile forces he'll o'erspread the land,</div>
                     <div class="line">And with the ostent of war will look so huge,</div>
                     <div class="line">Amazement shall drive courage from the state;</div>
                     <div class="line">Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist,</div>
                     <div class="line">And subjects punish'd that ne'er thought offence:</div>
                     <div class="line">Which care of them, not pity of myself,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who am no more but as the tops of trees,</div>
                     <div class="line">Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them,</div>
                     <div class="line">Makes both my body pine and soul to languish,</div>
                     <div class="line">And punish that before that he would punish.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter HELICANUS, with other Lords</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Second Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">And keep your mind, till you return to us,</div>
                     <div class="line">Peaceful and comfortable!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Peace, peace, and give experience tongue.</div>
                     <div class="line">They do abuse the king that flatter him:</div>
                     <div class="line">For flattery is the bellows blows up sin;</div>
                     <div class="line">The thing which is flatter'd, but a spark,</div>
                     <div class="line">To which that blast gives heat and stronger glowing;</div>
                     <div class="line">Whereas reproof, obedient and in order,</div>
                     <div class="line">Fits kings, as they are men, for they may err.</div>
                     <div class="line">When Signior Sooth here does proclaim a peace,</div>
                     <div class="line">He flatters you, makes war upon your life.</div>
                     <div class="line">Prince, pardon me, or strike me, if you please;</div>
                     <div class="line">I cannot be much lower than my knees.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlook</div>
                     <div class="line">What shipping and what lading's in our haven,</div>
                     <div class="line">And then return to us.</div>
                     <p>Exeunt Lords</p>
                     <div class="line">Helicanus, thou</div>
                     <div class="line">Hast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">An angry brow, dread lord.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">If there be such a dart in princes' frowns,</div>
                     <div class="line">How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">How dare the plants look up to heaven, from whence</div>
                     <div class="line">They have their nourishment?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Thou know'st I have power</div>
                     <div class="line">To take thy life from thee.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Kneeling</span>
                     </div>
                     <div class="line">I have ground the axe myself;</div>
                     <div class="line">Do you but strike the blow.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Rise, prithee, rise.</div>
                     <div class="line">Sit down: thou art no flatterer:</div>
                     <div class="line">I thank thee for it; and heaven forbid</div>
                     <div class="line">That kings should let their ears hear their</div>
                     <div class="line">faults hid!</div>
                     <div class="line">Fit counsellor and servant for a prince,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who by thy wisdom makest a prince thy servant,</div>
                     <div class="line">What wouldst thou have me do?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">To bear with patience</div>
                     <div class="line">Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Thou speak'st like a physician, Helicanus,</div>
                     <div class="line">That minister'st a potion unto me</div>
                     <div class="line">That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself.</div>
                     <div class="line">Attend me, then: I went to Antioch,</div>
                     <div class="line">Where as thou know'st, against the face of death,</div>
                     <div class="line">I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty.</div>
                     <div class="line">From whence an issue I might propagate,</div>
                     <div class="line">Are arms to princes, and bring joys to subjects.</div>
                     <div class="line">Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder;</div>
                     <div class="line">The rest--hark in thine ear--as black as incest:</div>
                     <div class="line">Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father</div>
                     <div class="line">Seem'd not to strike, but smooth: but thou</div>
                     <div class="line">know'st this,</div>
                     <div class="line">'Tis time to fear when tyrants seem to kiss.</div>
                     <div class="line">Such fear so grew in me, I hither fled,</div>
                     <div class="line">Under the covering of a careful night,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who seem'd my good protector; and, being here,</div>
                     <div class="line">Bethought me what was past, what might succeed.</div>
                     <div class="line">I knew him tyrannous; and tyrants' fears</div>
                     <div class="line">Decrease not, but grow faster than the years:</div>
                     <div class="line">And should he doubt it, as no doubt he doth,</div>
                     <div class="line">That I should open to the listening air</div>
                     <div class="line">How many worthy princes' bloods were shed,</div>
                     <div class="line">To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope,</div>
                     <div class="line">To lop that doubt, he'll fill this land with arms,</div>
                     <div class="line">And make pretence of wrong that I have done him:</div>
                     <div class="line">When all, for mine, if I may call offence,</div>
                     <div class="line">Must feel war's blow, who spares not innocence:</div>
                     <div class="line">Which love to all, of which thyself art one,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who now reprovest me for it,--</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Alas, sir!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,</div>
                     <div class="line">Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts</div>
                     <div class="line">How I might stop this tempest ere it came;</div>
                     <div class="line">And finding little comfort to relieve them,</div>
                     <div class="line">I thought it princely charity to grieve them.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak.</div>
                     <div class="line">Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear,</div>
                     <div class="line">And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who either by public war or private treason</div>
                     <div class="line">Will take away your life.</div>
                     <div class="line">Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while,</div>
                     <div class="line">Till that his rage and anger be forgot,</div>
                     <div class="line">Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life.</div>
                     <div class="line">Your rule direct to any; if to me.</div>
                     <div class="line">Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">I do not doubt thy faith;</div>
                     <div class="line">But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth,</div>
                     <div class="line">From whence we had our being and our birth.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tarsus</div>
                     <div class="line">Intend my travel, where I'll hear from thee;</div>
                     <div class="line">And by whose letters I'll dispose myself.</div>
                     <div class="line">The care I had and have of subjects' good</div>
                     <div class="line">On thee I lay whose wisdom's strength can bear it.</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath:</div>
                     <div class="line">Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both:</div>
                     <div class="line">But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe,</div>
                     <div class="line">That time of both this truth shall ne'er convince,</div>
                     <div class="line">Thou show'dst a subject's shine, I a true prince.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exeunt</p>
            </section>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.3.5">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>4. SCENE III.  Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter THALIARD</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">So, this is Tyre, and this the court. Here must I</div>
                     <div class="line">kill King Pericles; and if I do it not, I am sure to</div>
                     <div class="line">be hanged at home: 'tis dangerous. Well, I perceive</div>
                     <div class="line">he was a wise fellow, and had good discretion, that,</div>
                     <div class="line">being bid to ask what he would of the king, desired</div>
                     <div class="line">he might know none of his secrets: now do I see he</div>
                     <div class="line">had some reason for't; for if a king bid a man be a</div>
                     <div class="line">villain, he's bound by the indenture of his oath to</div>
                     <div class="line">be one! Hush! here come the lords of Tyre.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre,</div>
                     <div class="line">Further to question me of your king's departure:</div>
                     <div class="line">His seal'd commission, left in trust with me,</div>
                     <div class="line">Doth speak sufficiently he's gone to travel.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>  How! the king gone!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">If further yet you will be satisfied,</div>
                     <div class="line">Why, as it were unlicensed of your loves,</div>
                     <div class="line">He would depart, I'll give some light unto you.</div>
                     <div class="line">Being at Antioch--</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>          What from Antioch?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Royal Antiochus--on what cause I know not--</div>
                     <div class="line">Took some displeasure at him; at least he judged so:</div>
                     <div class="line">And doubting lest that he had err'd or sinn'd,</div>
                     <div class="line">To show his sorrow, he'ld correct himself;</div>
                     <div class="line">So puts himself unto the shipman's toil,</div>
                     <div class="line">With whom each minute threatens life or death.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>  Well, I perceive</div>
                     <div class="line">I shall not be hang'd now, although I would;</div>
                     <div class="line">But since he's gone, the king's seas must please:</div>
                     <div class="line">He 'scaped the land, to perish at the sea.</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll present myself. Peace to the lords of Tyre!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">THALIARD</div>
                     <div class="line">From him I come</div>
                     <div class="line">With message unto princely Pericles;</div>
                     <div class="line">But since my landing I have understood</div>
                     <div class="line">Your lord has betook himself to unknown travels,</div>
                     <div class="line">My message must return from whence it came.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">HELICANUS</div>
                     <div class="line">We have no reason to desire it,</div>
                     <div class="line">Commended to our master, not to us:</div>
                     <div class="line">Yet, ere you shall depart, this we desire,</div>
                     <div class="line">As friends to Antioch, we may feast in Tyre.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exeunt</p>
            </section>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.3.6">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>5. SCENE IV.  Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA,
and others</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">My Dionyza, shall we rest us here,</div>
                     <div class="line">And by relating tales of others' griefs,</div>
                     <div class="line">See if 'twill teach us to forget our own?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">DIONYZA</div>
                     <div class="line">That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it;</div>
                     <div class="line">For who digs hills because they do aspire</div>
                     <div class="line">Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher.</div>
                     <div class="line">O my distressed lord, even such our griefs are;</div>
                     <div class="line">Here they're but felt, and seen with mischief's eyes,</div>
                     <div class="line">But like to groves, being topp'd, they higher rise.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">O Dionyza,</div>
                     <div class="line">Who wanteth food, and will not say he wants it,</div>
                     <div class="line">Or can conceal his hunger till he famish?</div>
                     <div class="line">Our tongues and sorrows do sound deep</div>
                     <div class="line">Our woes into the air; our eyes do weep,</div>
                     <div class="line">Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim them louder;</div>
                     <div class="line">That, if heaven slumber while their creatures want,</div>
                     <div class="line">They may awake their helps to comfort them.</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll then discourse our woes, felt several years,</div>
                     <div class="line">And wanting breath to speak help me with tears.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">DIONYZA</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll do my best, sir.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">This Tarsus, o'er which I have the government,</div>
                     <div class="line">A city on whom plenty held full hand,</div>
                     <div class="line">For riches strew'd herself even in the streets;</div>
                     <div class="line">Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss'd the clouds,</div>
                     <div class="line">And strangers ne'er beheld but wondered at;</div>
                     <div class="line">Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn'd,</div>
                     <div class="line">Like one another's glass to trim them by:</div>
                     <div class="line">Their tables were stored full, to glad the sight,</div>
                     <div class="line">And not so much to feed on as delight;</div>
                     <div class="line">All poverty was scorn'd, and pride so great,</div>
                     <div class="line">The name of help grew odious to repeat.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">DIONYZA</div>
                     <div class="line">O, 'tis too true.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">But see what heaven can do! By this our change,</div>
                     <div class="line">These mouths, who but of late, earth, sea, and air,</div>
                     <div class="line">Were all too little to content and please,</div>
                     <div class="line">Although they gave their creatures in abundance,</div>
                     <div class="line">As houses are defiled for want of use,</div>
                     <div class="line">They are now starved for want of exercise:</div>
                     <div class="line">Those palates who, not yet two summers younger,</div>
                     <div class="line">Must have inventions to delight the taste,</div>
                     <div class="line">Would now be glad of bread, and beg for it:</div>
                     <div class="line">Those mothers who, to nousle up their babes,</div>
                     <div class="line">Thought nought too curious, are ready now</div>
                     <div class="line">To eat those little darlings whom they loved.</div>
                     <div class="line">So sharp are hunger's teeth, that man and wife</div>
                     <div class="line">Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life:</div>
                     <div class="line">Here stands a lord, and there a lady weeping;</div>
                     <div class="line">Here many sink, yet those which see them fall</div>
                     <div class="line">Have scarce strength left to give them burial.</div>
                     <div class="line">Is not this true?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">DIONYZA</div>
                     <div class="line">Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">O, let those cities that of plenty's cup</div>
                     <div class="line">And her prosperities so largely taste,</div>
                     <div class="line">With their superfluous riots, hear these tears!</div>
                     <div class="line">The misery of Tarsus may be theirs.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter a Lord</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">Where's the lord governor?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">Here.</div>
                     <div class="line">Speak out thy sorrows which thou bring'st in haste,</div>
                     <div class="line">For comfort is too far for us to expect.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">We have descried, upon our neighbouring shore,</div>
                     <div class="line">A portly sail of ships make hitherward.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">I thought as much.</div>
                     <div class="line">One sorrow never comes but brings an heir,</div>
                     <div class="line">That may succeed as his inheritor;</div>
                     <div class="line">And so in ours: some neighbouring nation,</div>
                     <div class="line">Taking advantage of our misery,</div>
                     <div class="line">Hath stuff'd these hollow vessels with their power,</div>
                     <div class="line">To beat us down, the which are down already;</div>
                     <div class="line">And make a conquest of unhappy me,</div>
                     <div class="line">Whereas no glory's got to overcome.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">That's the least fear; for, by the semblance</div>
                     <div class="line">Of their white flags display'd, they bring us peace,</div>
                     <div class="line">And come to us as favourers, not as foes.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">Thou speak'st like him's untutor'd to repeat:</div>
                     <div class="line">Who makes the fairest show means most deceit.</div>
                     <div class="line">But bring they what they will and what they can,</div>
                     <div class="line">What need we fear?</div>
                     <div class="line">The ground's the lowest, and we are half way there.</div>
                     <div class="line">Go tell their general we attend him here,</div>
                     <div class="line">To know for what he comes, and whence he comes,</div>
                     <div class="line">And what he craves.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Lord</div>
                     <div class="line">I go, my lord.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist;</div>
                     <div class="line">If wars, we are unable to resist.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter PERICLES with Attendants</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Lord governor, for so we hear you are,</div>
                     <div class="line">Let not our ships and number of our men</div>
                     <div class="line">Be like a beacon fired to amaze your eyes.</div>
                     <div class="line">We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre,</div>
                     <div class="line">And seen the desolation of your streets:</div>
                     <div class="line">Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears,</div>
                     <div class="line">But to relieve them of their heavy load;</div>
                     <div class="line">And these our ships, you happily may think</div>
                     <div class="line">Are like the Trojan horse was stuff'd within</div>
                     <div class="line">With bloody veins, expecting overthrow,</div>
                     <div class="line">Are stored with corn to make your needy bread,</div>
                     <div class="line">And give them life whom hunger starved half dead.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">All</div>
                     <div class="line">The gods of Greece protect you!</div>
                     <div class="line">And we'll pray for you.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Arise, I pray you, rise:</div>
                     <div class="line">We do not look for reverence, but to love,</div>
                     <div class="line">And harbourage for ourself, our ships, and men.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">CLEON</div>
                     <div class="line">The which when any shall not gratify,</div>
                     <div class="line">Or pay you with unthankfulness in thought,</div>
                     <div class="line">Be it our wives, our children, or ourselves,</div>
                     <div class="line">The curse of heaven and men succeed their evils!</div>
                     <div class="line">Till when,--the which I hope shall ne'er be seen,--</div>
                     <div class="line">Your grace is welcome to our town and us.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Which welcome we'll accept; feast here awhile,</div>
                     <div class="line">Until our stars that frown lend us a smile.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exeunt</p>
            </section>
         </article>
         <article class="chapter" id="R.1.4">
            <header class="chapter-titlepage">
               <h2>Chapter 2. ACT II</h2>
            </header>
            <div class="lists-of-titles">
               <div class="toc">
                  <p>
                     <b>Table of Contents</b>
                  </p>
                  <ul class="toc">
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.2">1. [Prologue]</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.3">2. SCENE I.  Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.4">3. SCENE II.  The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.5">4. SCENE III.  The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.6">5. SCENE IV.  Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                        <span>
                           <a href="#R.1.4.7">6. SCENE V.  Pentapolis. A room in the palace.</a>
                        </span>
                     </li>
                  </ul>
               </div>
            </div>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.4.2">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>1. [Prologue]</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter GOWER</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">GOWER</div>
                     <div class="line">Here have you seen a mighty king</div>
                     <div class="line">His child, I wis, to incest bring;</div>
                     <div class="line">A better prince and benign lord,</div>
                     <div class="line">That will prove awful both in deed and word.</div>
                     <div class="line">Be quiet then as men should be,</div>
                     <div class="line">Till he hath pass'd necessity.</div>
                     <div class="line">I'll show you those in troubles reign,</div>
                     <div class="line">Losing a mite, a mountain gain.</div>
                     <div class="line">The good in conversation,</div>
                     <div class="line">To whom I give my benison,</div>
                     <div class="line">Is still at Tarsus, where each man</div>
                     <div class="line">Thinks all is writ he speken can;</div>
                     <div class="line">And, to remember what he does,</div>
                     <div class="line">Build his statue to make him glorious:</div>
                     <div class="line">But tidings to the contrary</div>
                     <div class="line">Are brought your eyes; what need speak I?</div>
                     <h3 class="bridgehead">DUMB SHOW.</h3>
                     <p>Enter at one door PERICLES talking with CLEON; all
the train with them. Enter at another door a
Gentleman, with a letter to PERICLES; PERICLES
shows the letter to CLEON; gives the Messenger a
reward, and knights him. Exit PERICLES at one
door, and CLEON at another</p>
                     <div class="line">Good Helicane, that stay'd at home,</div>
                     <div class="line">Not to eat honey like a drone</div>
                     <div class="line">From others' labours; for though he strive</div>
                     <div class="line">To killen bad, keep good alive;</div>
                     <div class="line">And to fulfil his prince' desire,</div>
                     <div class="line">Sends word of all that haps in Tyre:</div>
                     <div class="line">How Thaliard came full bent with sin</div>
                     <div class="line">And had intent to murder him;</div>
                     <div class="line">And that in Tarsus was not best</div>
                     <div class="line">Longer for him to make his rest.</div>
                     <div class="line">He, doing so, put forth to seas,</div>
                     <div class="line">Where when men been, there's seldom ease;</div>
                     <div class="line">For now the wind begins to blow;</div>
                     <div class="line">Thunder above and deeps below</div>
                     <div class="line">Make such unquiet, that the ship</div>
                     <div class="line">Should house him safe is wreck'd and split;</div>
                     <div class="line">And he, good prince, having all lost,</div>
                     <div class="line">By waves from coast to coast is tost:</div>
                     <div class="line">All perishen of man, of pelf,</div>
                     <div class="line">Ne aught escapen but himself;</div>
                     <div class="line">Till fortune, tired with doing bad,</div>
                     <div class="line">Threw him ashore, to give him glad:</div>
                     <div class="line">And here he comes. What shall be next,</div>
                     <div class="line">Pardon old Gower,--this longs the text.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Exit</p>
            </section>
            <section class="section" id="R.1.4.3">
               <div class="section-titlepage">
                  <h2>2. SCENE I.  Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.</h2>
               </div>
               <p>Enter PERICLES, wet</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven!</div>
                     <div class="line">Wind, rain, and thunder, remember, earthly man</div>
                     <div class="line">Is but a substance that must yield to you;</div>
                     <div class="line">And I, as fits my nature, do obey you:</div>
                     <div class="line">Alas, the sea hath cast me on the rocks,</div>
                     <div class="line">Wash'd me from shore to shore, and left me breath</div>
                     <div class="line">Nothing to think on but ensuing death:</div>
                     <div class="line">Let it suffice the greatness of your powers</div>
                     <div class="line">To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes;</div>
                     <div class="line">And having thrown him from your watery grave,</div>
                     <div class="line">Here to have death in peace is all he'll crave.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <p>Enter three FISHERMEN</p>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">What, ho, Pilch!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Second Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Ha, come and bring away the nets!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">What, Patch-breech, I say!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">What say you, master?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Look how thou stirrest now! come away, or I'll</div>
                     <div class="line">fetch thee with a wanion.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Faith, master, I am thinking of the poor men that</div>
                     <div class="line">were cast away before us even now.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear what</div>
                     <div class="line">pitiful cries they made to us to help them, when,</div>
                     <div class="line">well-a-day, we could scarce help ourselves.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Nay, master, said not I as much when I saw the</div>
                     <div class="line">porpus how he bounced and tumbled? they say</div>
                     <div class="line">they're half fish, half flesh: a plague on them,</div>
                     <div class="line">they ne'er come but I look to be washed. Master, I</div>
                     <div class="line">marvel how the fishes live in the sea.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">First Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Why, as men do a-land; the great ones eat up the</div>
                     <div class="line">little ones: I can compare our rich misers to</div>
                     <div class="line">nothing so fitly as to a whale; a' plays and</div>
                     <div class="line">tumbles, driving the poor fry before him, and at</div>
                     <div class="line">last devours them all at a mouthful: such whales</div>
                     <div class="line">have I heard on o' the land, who never leave gaping</div>
                     <div class="line">till they've swallowed the whole parish, church,</div>
                     <div class="line">steeple, bells, and all.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>  A pretty moral.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would have</div>
                     <div class="line">been that day in the belfry.</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Second Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Why, man?</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
                     <div class="line">Because he should have swallowed me too: and when I</div>
                     <div class="line">had been in his belly, I would have kept such a</div>
                     <div class="line">jangling of the bells, that he should never have</div>
                     <div class="line">left, till he cast bells, steeple, church, and</div>
                     <div class="line">parish up again. But if the good King Simonides</div>
                     <div class="line">were of my mind,--</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">PERICLES</div>
                     <div class="line">
                        <span>Aside</span>  Simonides!</div>
                  </div>
               </div>
               <div class="dialogue">
                  <div class="linegroup">
                     <div class="speaker">Third Fisherman</div>
